div.p: Examining Visual-Spatial Paths for Mobile Authentication
Taehoon Lee, David Lu, Sauvik Das, Jason Hong
Strong passwords for existing authentication methods are difficult for users to remember/ recall
Many smartphone users have low entropy passwords that have low adversary protection
42% of smartphone users use no form of authentication
Memorability: How easily retainable is our secret
Security: The security level of our authentication system
Adversary Protection: How easily can someone steal the password
The user visualizes a spatial path within a virtual space (palace) to recall information
Humans are better at remembering visual-spatial information than they are at remembering abstract information
The user creates a password stored in the form of a path through a virtual world consisting of rooms
Wall decorations and items in these rooms serve as visual guides
The user then can authenticate his/her device by drawing the exact path that corresponds to their password
We decided to run two user studies to validate our idea:
While The Memory Palace is shown to be a strong security solution, it also
provides many other applications as well.
